# Project Shaping
	- ## Lean Canvas
		- **Problem:** Identify the top 1-3 problems that your target customers face. This section also often includes listing existing alternatives that customers currently use to address these problems.
			- The children are stressed and bored in an overwhelming unfamiliar environment
			- Waiting, boredom, buildup of stress
			- Entertainment
			- Over medicalisation
			- Cost
		- **Customer Segments:** Define your target audience or the specific groups of people or organizations you aim to reach and serve. It's also useful to identify early adopters within these segments.
			- Physical location
				- NHS north england
				- Dubai
				- Private retreats
				- Spire
				- Christies
				- Priory
				- Any EU quiet zones
			- Companion app
				- Local authorities
				- Schools (ed tech problem)
				- Parents
				- Entertainers
				- Kids festivals
				- Pop ups
				- Carnival
				-
		- **Unique Value Proposition (UVP):** Articulate a clear, compelling message that states why your product or service is different and worth buying. This often includes a high-level concept, which is a short, memorable tagline or analogy (e.g., "Flickr for videos").
			- Modern magical emotional physical practice, grounded in real world research austim
		-
		- **Solution:** Briefly outline your proposed product or service that will address the identified problems for your customer segments.
			-
		- **Channels:** Describe the pathways through which you will reach your customer segments to deliver your value proposition. This includes marketing, sales, and distribution channels.
			- Physical marketing, professionals and practitioners
			- Online marketing to parents, autism charities, providers etc
			- Local authorities
			- Contacts abroad
			- Personal networks of parents and children
		-
		- **Revenue Streams:** Explain how your business will generate income from each customer segment. This includes pricing models and lifetime value considerations.
			- Subscription service
			- Marketing existing practice
		-
		- **Cost Structure:** List all the operational costs associated with running your business, including customer acquisition costs, hosting, development, and other fixed and variable expenses.
			-
		- **Key Metrics:** Identify the key activities and numbers you will track to measure the performance and success of your business. These are the indicators that show how your business is doing.
			- number of signups
			- installations
		-
		- **Unfair Advantage (or Differentiator):** Describe what makes your business difficult to copy or buy by competitors. This could be insider information, a strong network, a "dream team," existing customers, patents, or a unique brand.
			- rich history narrative
			- experience
			- Decades of established practice
			- Contacts (NHS and abroad)
			- scientific literature

- # Innovate Bid
	- The DCMS Create Growth Programme Competition 4: Small Projects is a funding opportunity for UK-registered micro, small, and medium-sized creative businesses. It aims to help these businesses scale, innovate, and build investor networks[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[4](https://ukft.org/create-growth-4/)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
	- **Key Details**
		- **Who can apply:**Â Micro, small, or medium-sized enterprises in the creative industries, registered or operational in one of 12 designated regions (including Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire, West Midlands, and others)[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[4](https://ukft.org/create-growth-4/)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
		- **Funding available:**Â Â£20,000â€“Â£50,000 per project, 100% funded (no match funding required)[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[3](https://iuk-business-connect.org.uk/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
		- **Eligible projects:**Â Must be new to your business, demonstrate a clear growth opportunity, and show a route to commercialisation within 12 months[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
		- **Support includes:**Â Business support, access to finance, and investor capacity-building activities[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[3](https://iuk-business-connect.org.uk/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
		- **Application window:**Â Opens 31 March 2025, closes 29 May 2025 at 11:00am UK time[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
		- **One application per business:**Â You can only apply to one strand (small or large projects) and only once per competition round[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[2](https://tbat.co.uk/funding-calls/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/)[3](https://iuk-business-connect.org.uk/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).
	- **Eligibility Criteria**
		- Must be from the creative industries sector (as defined by DCMS)
		- Business must be based in one of the 12 appointed regions
		- Project must be innovative, ambitious, and offer clear growth potential
		- Must engage with, or plan to engage with, regional Create Growth Programme support[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[5](https://www.barbicancreativehub.com/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/)
	- **How to Apply**
		- Submit your application through the Innovate UK portal before the deadline
		- Ensure your project fits the funding criteria and regional requirements
		- Only eligible project costs will be funded; subcontractor costs are allowed but capped at 75% of total costs[2](https://tbat.co.uk/funding-calls/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/)
		- This programme is highly competitive and aims to fund a diverse portfolio of projects across regions and creative sub-sectors[1](https://apply-for-innovation-funding.service.gov.uk/competition/2153/overview/e2fe0532-43b8-40b6-aab5-8e08ee974f46)[2](https://tbat.co.uk/funding-calls/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/)[3](https://iuk-business-connect.org.uk/opportunities/dcms-create-growth-programme-competition-4-small-projects/).

- # Pitch deck template
	- Here's a common flow for a pitch deck:
	- **Cover/Title Slide**
		- **Company Name & Logo:** Clear and prominent.
		- **Tagline/One-Liner:** A concise and compelling description of what your company does (e.g., "We are the Airbnb for pet services" or "Revolutionizing X for Y market").
		- **(Optional) Your Name & Title**
		- **(Optional) Contact Information** (though this can also go on the final slide)
		- **Date**
	- **Problem**
		- **What is the Pain Point?:** Clearly describe the specific problem your target customers are facing.
		- **Why is it a Significant Problem?:** Explain the impact of this problem (e.g., time wasted, money lost, frustration).
		- **Who Experiences This Problem?:** Briefly introduce your target customer.
		- **How Are People Currently Solving This (or Trying To)?:** Describe the existing alternatives or the status quo and why they are inadequate.
		- *Goal: Get the audience to nod in agreement and understand the urgency and relevance of the problem.*
	- **Solution**
		- **Introduce Your Product/Service:** Clearly explain what your solution is.
		- **How Does it Solve the Problem?:** Directly address the pain points you outlined.
		- **What are the Key Benefits?:** Focus on the value you provide to the customer (e.g., saves time, reduces cost, improves efficiency, provides a better experience).
		- **Show, Don't Just Tell:** Use mockups, screenshots, a short demo video link, or compelling visuals if possible.
		- *Goal: Clearly demonstrate how your offering provides a better way.*
	- **Product (Optional, or can be combined with Solution)**
		- **How it Works:** A brief overview of the technology or process.
		- **Key Features:** Highlight 2-4 core features that deliver the main benefits.
		- **Technology Stack (if relevant and a differentiator):** Briefly mention key technologies if they provide a competitive edge.
		- **Development Stage/Roadmap (briefly):** Where are you now, and what are the next key product milestones?
		- *Goal: Give a tangible sense of your product and its capabilities.*
	- **Market Opportunity / Market Size**
		- **Define Your Target Market:** Be specific. Who are your ideal customers?
		- **Total Addressable Market (TAM):** The total market demand for your type of product/service.
		- **Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM):** The segment of the TAM targeted by your products/services which is within your geographical reach.
		- **Serviceable Obtainable Market (SOM) / Target Market:** The portion of SAM that you can realistically capture in the near future (e.g., next 3-5 years).
		- **Market Trends & Growth Potential:** Why is this market attractive now? Is it growing?
		- *Goal: Convince investors that the market is large enough for a significant return on investment.*
	- **Business Model**
		- **How Do You Make Money?:** Clearly explain your revenue streams (e.g., subscription fees, direct sales, advertising, commissions, freemium model).
		- **Pricing Strategy:** How much do you charge? How does this compare to alternatives?
		- **Customer Lifetime Value (LTV) (if applicable/calculable):** The total revenue you expect from a single customer account.
		- **Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) (if applicable/calculable):** How much it costs you to acquire a new paying customer.
		- *Goal: Show a clear and viable path to generating revenue and profitability.*
	- **Traction / Milestones Achieved (Proof of Concept)**
		- **What Have You Accomplished So Far?:**
			- Key product development milestones (e.g., MVP launched, beta testing).
			- Early sales or revenue numbers.
			- Number of users, customers, or sign-ups.
			- Key partnerships established.
			- Significant press, awards, or recognition.
			- Positive testimonials or case studies.
		- **Show Growth Trends:** Use charts or graphs if possible (e.g., month-over-month user growth).
		- *Goal: Demonstrate momentum and reduce perceived risk by showing evidence of market validation and execution capabilities.*
	- **Go-to-Market Strategy / Sales & Marketing**
		- **How Will You Reach Your Target Customers?:**
			- Key marketing channels (e.g., content marketing, social media, SEO, paid ads, partnerships).
			- Sales strategy (e.g., direct sales team, online sales, channel partners).
		- **Customer Acquisition Plan:** How will you attract and convert customers efficiently?
		- **Early Successes:** What channels have already shown promise?
		- *Goal: Outline a realistic and effective plan for acquiring customers and growing your market share.*
	- **Competition**
		- **Who Are Your Main Competitors?:** Identify direct and indirect competitors.
		- **How Do You Differentiate?:** What is your unique selling proposition (USP) or "unfair advantage" compared to them? (e.g., superior technology, better user experience, different business model, stronger community, key partnerships, IP).
		- **Competitive Matrix/Analysis (Optional but often effective):** A simple table comparing your solution against competitors on key features, pricing, etc.
		- **Barriers to Entry (if any):** What makes it difficult for new players (or existing ones) to replicate what you do?
		- *Goal: Show that you understand the competitive landscape and have a clear advantage.* (Never say you have no competitors).
	- **Team**
		- **Founders & Key Team Members:** Names, photos (optional), and roles.
		- **Relevant Experience & Expertise:** Highlight experience that directly relates to the problem you're solving or the market you're entering. Why is *this* the team to make this venture successful?
		- **Advisors (Optional):** If you have prominent or highly relevant advisors, you can mention them.
		- **Missing Key Roles (and plan to fill them - if applicable):** Be honest about gaps and how you plan to address them.
		- *Goal: Instill confidence that you have the right people to execute the plan.*
	- **Financial Projections (Keep it High-Level)**
		- **Key Assumptions:** Briefly state the main assumptions behind your projections.
		- **3-5 Year Forecast:** Typically includes revenue, key expenses (COGS, OpEx), and profitability (EBITDA or Net Profit).
		- **Key Metrics:** Highlight a few critical metrics that drive your financial model (e.g., number of customers, conversion rates, average revenue per user).
		- **Use a Simple Chart or Table:** Make it easy to read and understand.
		- *Goal: Show that you've thought about the financial viability and scalability of your business. Projections are understood to be estimates, but the underlying logic is important.*
	- **The Ask (Funding Request)**
		- **How Much Funding Are You Seeking?:** Be specific.
		- **Use of Funds:** Clearly outline how you plan to allocate the investment (e.g., product development, sales & marketing, hiring key personnel, expanding operations). Link this to achieving key milestones.
		- **What Milestones Will This Funding Help You Achieve?:** Be clear about what the investment will enable you to do (e.g., reach X users, Y revenue, launch Z product).
		- **(Optional) Current Funding/Previous Rounds:** If applicable.
		- *Goal: Clearly state your funding needs and how it will fuel growth.*
	- **Contact Information / Thank You**
		- **Company Name & Logo**
		- **Your Name, Title, Email, Phone Number, Website**
		- **A Simple "Thank You"**
		- **(Optional) A compelling closing statement or reiteration of your vision.**
		- **Appendix (Optional Slides - Have them ready if asked)**
	- Detailed Financial Model & Assumptions
	- In-depth Market Research Data
	- More Detailed Product Screenshots/Tech Architecture
	- Customer Testimonials/Case Studies
	- Letters of Intent (LOIs) or Partnership Details
	- IP Details (Patents, Trademarks)
	- Exit Strategy (very early stage might not need this in detail, but good to have thought about it)
	- Detailed Team Bios

- # Transcript summary
- **Core Idea & Evolution:**
- The initial concept is to create an interactive digital platform, potentially a subscription service for hospitals or a "companion agent," inspired by high-tech experiences in places like Dubai. The goal is to move beyond simple videos to a real-time, AI-backed interactive experience.
- **Key Features & Requirements Discussed:**
- **Interactivity:** Crucial. Not just passive video consumption.
- **"No-Touch" Interface:** Essential for hygiene in hospitals.
- **AI-Backed:** For real-time interaction, safety, trust, and governance (awareness of EU AI Act).
- **Motion Capture:** To translate real-life performance (specifically the user's "clown doctor" dance) into the digital realm.
- **User Experience (UX):** Intuitive, accessible (scalable for different abilities), and engaging.
- **Content:** Leverages the user's existing "clown doctor" persona and dance. The idea of an AI model overtrained on her dance videos to generate endless, stylized dance is a key technical proposal.
- **Hardware for MVP:**
	- Portable, transparent, stick-on LED film display (safe, wipeable, relatively cheap).
	- Pixel streaming from a central GPU (for training the AI and serving content) to low-cost units at locations.
- **Context-Awareness:** Potential for the system to know about weather, outside world etc.
  
  **Business & Strategy (using Lean Canvas & Pitch Deck frameworks):**
- **Problem:** Stress, boredom, overwhelm for children (especially autistic) in hospitals or waiting situations, leading to over-medicalization or difficulties with procedures.
- **Target Audience:**
	- Initially: Hospitals (especially high-end or specialist ones).
	- Pivoted towards: A broader market for a "companion app" (parents, schools, local authorities for quiet zones, entertainers, festivals). The age group of 3-10 years is identified as a starting focus for comprehensibility and ethical research.
- **Unique Value Proposition (UVP):** "Modern magic based on tradition," leveraging the user's generational clowning history, established NHS/international contacts, and unique dance style.
- **Revenue Model:**
	- Short-term MVP: Selling a physical, portable interactive display unit on-site after a performance.
	- Long-term: Subscription service for a companion app.
- **Channels:** Physical marketing/demos for institutions, online marketing via charities/professionals for the app.
- **Funding Goal:** The immediate aim is to secure funding for research, UX design, a demonstrator/MVP, and primary testing, rather than a full market launch. The project needs to show "clear growth potential." A budget of ~Â£15k for the initial tech loadout is mentioned.
  
  **Key Decisions & Insights:**
- The "companion app" direct to consumers is likely more scalable and economically viable long-term than just hospital subscriptions.
- However, the immediate MVP should be a tangible, sellable physical unit (the transparent LED display system) that the user can deploy in her existing practice. This is less fraught with AI governance risks for initial funding.
- The "unfair advantage" lies in the user's unique personal history, performance style, and existing network.
- A recent research paper on AI-generated dance from video offers a cutting-edge technical path for the interactive dance component.
  
  **Action Items:**
- **User (Lucy Wilkinson):**
	- Develop the marketing narrative (backward/forward story, pitch).
	- Compile her dance videos (from YouTube etc.) for the AI model training.
	- Refine the MVP concept to best suit her needs and be easily deployable/sellable.
- **Facilitator/Team:**
	- Conduct a research piece on the AI dance model and transparent LED tech.
	- Develop a contact list for partnerships and support.
	- Build out the team description for the funding bid.
	- Prepare a tech demo/proof-of-concept.
- **Hayden (Animator):** Character building for the digital persona.
